title: 108_hr4855
content: The "Independent National Security Classification Board Act of 2004" establishes an Independent National Security Classification Board to review and propose new standards for the classification system of national security information. The Board will also make recommendations on current and new information classifications. The Independent National Security Classification Board is established as an independent agency in the executive branch. It is composed of members appointed by the President, Senate, and House of Representatives, each knowledgeable on classification matters. Members serve a 5-year term and may be reappointed for an additional term. The Board operates independently and fills vacancies in the same manner as original appointments. It has its own office, selects a Chairman from its members, and meets at the Chairman's call. A majority constitutes a quorum, but fewer members can hold hearings. Decision-making may be classified, but final decisions and reports are made public. The Board must make initial appointments within 90 days of the Act's enactment and hold its first meeting within 30 days of all members being appointed. A website must be established within 90 days of all appointments. The Board is responsible for carrying out specific duties as outlined in the Act. The Board is tasked with reviewing the classification system for national security information, recommending reforms to ensure protection of national security, information sharing among government agencies, and public discussion of security issues. They will consult with relevant Senate committees during this review. The Board will submit a report on the proposed scope of review to the President and relevant committees of Congress for comment, with the President having 30 days to notify the Board of any revisions to the scope of review. The Board will prescribe the classification system for national security information, applicable to all US departments and agencies. It will review the system and provide findings and recommendations to the President and Congress for new procedures and standards. Each congressional committee can submit comments on the proposed scope of review. The Board will adopt a classification system for national security information within 180 days of all members being confirmed. The system will be used for classifying all national security information. The Board will review classification decisions made by Executive agencies and have access to all relevant documents. The Board will have access to classified documents containing national security information and will review classification requests from authorized individuals or congressional committees. The Board, under the Committee on International Relations or the Permanent Select Committee on Intelligence of the House of Representatives, may recommend to the President on classifying or declassifying documents for national security. The President must either accept and implement the recommendation or respond within 60 days. The Board may recommend classifying or declassifying documents for national security to the President. If the President does not accept the recommendation, a justification must be provided to Congress and posted on the Board's website. The Board is exempt from the Freedom of Information Act and will create regulations to implement this process. The term "Executive agency" is defined in this section as per section 105 of title 5, United States Code. SEC. 5. POWERS OF BOARD. The Board has the authority to hold hearings, gather information from Federal agencies, receive administrative support services, and utilize postal services as needed to fulfill its responsibilities under this Act. The Board has the authority to accept gifts or donations of services or property from Federal Government agencies. The Board has the authority to accept gifts or donations of services or property from Federal Government agencies. SEC. 6. BOARD PERSONNEL MATTERS. The Chairman of the Independent National Security Classification Board has the authority to appoint an executive director and additional staff without following civil service laws. The Chairman can also determine their compensation independently. The Chairman of the Independent National Security Classification Board has the authority to appoint an executive director and staff with pay rates not exceeding level V of the Executive Schedule. Federal Government employees can be detailed to the Board without reimbursement, maintaining their civil service status. Authorization of appropriations for the Board is set at $2,000,000 for fiscal year 2005, with additional funding as needed in the future.
